title: 104_hr3274
content: The amendment to Section 315 of the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 limits contributions from non-local individuals to candidates for the House of Representatives. Candidates cannot accept more than 50% of contributions from non-local individuals in their district or more than 10% from non-local individuals in their state. The Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 has been amended to reduce the limitation amount for contributions by a multicandidate political committee to House of Representatives candidates. Additionally, a ban on soft money has been introduced, imposing limitations and reporting requirements for amounts paid for mixed political activities. The Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 has been amended to reduce contribution limits for multicandidate political committees to House of Representatives candidates. A ban on soft money has been implemented, requiring limitations and reporting for payments related to mixed political activities. The Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 has been amended to repeal the building fund exception to the definition of the term "contribution." This involves striking out clause (viii) and redesignating clauses (ix) through (xiv) as clauses (viii) through (xiii), respectively. Amendments to the Communications Act of 1934 are being made. Amendments to the Communications Act of 1934 include changes to Section 315 regarding broadcasting station usage by political candidates. Amendments to Section 315 of the Communications Act of 1934 allow legally qualified candidates to purchase advertising spots on broadcasting stations. If a program is preempted, candidate advertising spots may also be preempted. Additionally, the lowest charge for advertising purposes is specified. The amendments to Section 315 of the Communications Act of 1934 specify the time intervals for determining advertising rates for elections.
